attributes.title: Stock Verification
attributes.description: Physical stock counted compared to SAP inventory warehouse balances revealed variances as follows; Bread had -64.50 loaves, White Flour had -5.184kg, Utto had +2.93 Litres, Wheat bran had -27.6kg, Polybags had -1473 pieces, while crates had +22 pieces. The rest of the stock items had minimal or zero variances as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation:
Controls should be enhanced on finished products to eliminate variance noted. 

Branch Manager should always follow up on Wheat bran good issue posting to eliminate variance noted.

Accurate records of production polybags should be maintained with daily follow up good issue raised to eliminate variance noted.
attributes.effect: Variations noted on various stock items is an indication of weak controls.

value:
Variance in crates was as a result of 22 crates recovered on 8th June 2024 on Shujaa route which was still showing a balance. This has been adjusted accordingly.

I will follow up polybags damages recording by the supervisors and good issue raised to eliminate variance noted.

I will also ensure wheat bran consumption is correctly captured on good issue on daily basis.
We shall strengthen controls on all stock items to curb cases of variations noted.

In the prior audit, it was noted that;

  • Polybags had a variance of +161 pieces

  • The finished product had a variance of -18.25 pieces

  • Utto oil had a variance of +1 .091 Litres/Kgs

  • Wheat Bran had a variation of -16.801 Kgs

  • Yeast had a variance of -2.038 pieces

  • White flour had -10.107 Kgs.

A stock take was conducted on 16th June 2025 to verify whether the physical inventory matched the stock book balances recorded in the SAP system and to assess the effectiveness of internal stock control procedures
Variations was noted on various stock items which is an indication of weak controls.
Operations/Production Department
To evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of existing controls designed to safeguard various stock items.

attributes.title: Bread weight Check
attributes.description: From the packed bread sample selected,  there were minimal cases of underweight noted as illustrated in the table below;
attributes.recommendation: The Branch management should maintain the controls in place on finished product weight.
attributes.effect: Minimal cases of underweight implies that the company is cautioned against possible penalties as well as reputational damage.

value: We shall continue to follow the standard procedures to ensure the final product meets the recommended weight.
I commend the branch on final product weight achieved and we shall ensure this is maintained.
In the prior audit, packed bread weight check as shown below;

Bread weight check was done by selecting a sample from packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market. The aim was to establish whether the bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.
There were minimal cases of underweight noted
Operations/Production Department
To ensure bread dispatched to the markets meets the recommended weight standards.

attributes.title: Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Audit noted that production damages were averaging at 0.33% of the total production and market damages stood at 1.63% of the total sales for the 30 days period as illustrated below;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Further, Physical verification of damages revealed that there was a variation of -185.97kgs between what was recorded and what was sent to ingredients as illustrated below;
attributes.recommendation:
• Production procedures should strictly observed to minimize high rate of production damages.
  • Sales team should do proper daily analysis of demand and supply to minimize the high rate of market damages associated with supermarket returns.
  • Maintaining accurate records of damages and accountability to ensure damages recorded equates damages sent to the ingredients.
attributes.effect: Production and Market damages exceeding the acceptable rates implies that the company forfeited more revenue than what was provided for in provisions. Excess production damages resulted to revenue forfeiture of Kes. 77,168  while excess market damages resulted for revenue forfeiture of Kes.  500,479

value: We have had issues with two oven in unit 2 leading to cases production damages but I will closely monitor production to ensure production damages are at the acceptable level.
I urge the branch manager to ensure production is closely monitored and where the causes are out negligence action to be taken on the culprits.

The production damages were at 0.31% of the total production which was above the set standard of 0.2% with a cost implication of KES 70,421.63.
The market damages  were at 1.27% of the total sales (supermarket damages), which was above the 1% allowed limit and had a cost implication of KES 229,585.31

Analysis of production and market damages was done for a period of 30 days from 17th May 2025 to 15th June 2025 to assess whether production and market damages were within the desired rates of 0.20% of the total production and 1% of the total sales respectively.
Both Production and Market damages exceeded the acceptable rates of 0.2% and 1% respectively.
Operations/Production Department
To assess whether production and market damages were within the desired rates of 0.20% of the total production and 1% of the total sales respectively.

attributes.title: Mixing charts analysis
attributes.description:
Analysis of Physical mixing charts compared to SAP mixing charts summary for the period was as illustrated below;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Audit noted that, Average production for the period was 195.50 bags per day, which is 91% of the daily target of 216 bags. Combined yield achieved by the two units during this period was 190.98. 

The table below shows summarized findings of the mixing chart production analysis.


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Audit noted that the actual production BOM for the two units are different whereas the system production BOM used is for unit 1 irrespective of the variations thereof.
attributes.recommendation:
The actual production BOM for the two units should be harmonized as the two units operates as one branch. 

The branch should strive to achieve 100% production capacity utilization as the sales levels exceeds the production capacity thus relying on other branches to fulfil orders.
attributes.effect: Accurate data processing provide for informed decision making. The 9% idle capacity in the branch implies that the branch does not fully exploit the existing capacity.

value: Instances of variety controls and oven breakdown contributed to the slight failure to achieve 100% production capacity.
I will follow up on BOM harmonization for the two units with the ROM

In the prior audit, it was noted that; the average yield was 190.91 loaves per bag, Average production was 197.72 bags equivalent to 91.54 % of the set target of 216 bags, Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1, No cases of remixes were noted for the period under audit.

An analysis of mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 30 days from 17th May 2025 to 15th June 2025, to confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP,  raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved.
The branch achieved yield was within the desired combined yield. Production capacity utilization was at 91% hence there exist room for improvement.
Operations/Production Department
To assess production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP,  raw materials usage as per the set BOM, production yield and if the set production standards were achieved

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description: Audit noted that, production workers efficiency was at 4.35 bags per worker which is slightly above the KPI of 4.3 bags per worker as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation: The controls on hired production workers in place should be maintained
attributes.effect: Achieved KPI implies that the company did not incur unbudgeted cost on production labor

value: We shall continue to monitor production workers to maintain the efficiency.
This is well noted, we will maintain
In the prior audit, it was noted that production efficiency was at 4.35 which was achieved as per the KPI.

Production efficiency was analyzed for a period of 30 days from 17th May 2025 to 15th June 2025. The aim was to assess if the production workers hired achieved the set production efficiency level of 4.3 bags per worker.
The set KPI was achieved for the period analyzed.
Operations/Production Department
To assess if the production workers hired achieved the set production efficiency level of 4.3 bags per worker.

attributes.title: Packing efficiency
attributes.description: Audit noted that,  packing efficiency for the period was 91.28 crates per slicer hired.
attributes.recommendation:
The branch management should ensure slicers are hired as per available workload. 

Close supervision of the hired slice to make sure they achieve the set KPI
attributes.effect: Failure to achieve the set KPI implies that the company spent Kes. 43,776 unbudgeted labor costs over the 30 days period.

value: We will improve on packers supervision to ensure they achieve the KPI.
We shall engage our supervisors to ensure there is efficient supervision of the slicers to eliminate the inefficiency noted.
In the prior audit, it was noted that, for the period 16th April 2025-16th May2025, the packing efficiency stood at 92.99 crates per packer, which was below the KPI of 97 crates per packer
Slicing efficiency was calculated over a 30-days period, from 17th May 2025 to 15th June 2025, to determine whether the KPI of 97 crates per slicer was being met.
The KPI was not met, which implies that the company spent more on slicing labor than the budgeted.
Operations/Production Department
To assess whether the KPI of 97 crates per slicer was being met.

attributes.title: Vehicle consumption analysis
attributes.description: Audit noted that most vehicle in the branch consumed within the set standards except for three vehicles KDB 197D, KCG 204S and KCK 047X  which were found to be overconsuming.
attributes.recommendation:
Close monitoring of vehicles with saving on fuel for a possible standard rate review.

Further investigation on vehicles which are overconsuming to get the root cause.
attributes.effect: Cases of consumption variations from the set standards is an indication that there is need to re-evaluate the actual standards.

value: We shall continue to monitor consumption as per the set standards
I will ensure we recover fuel from drivers who are found to be overconsuming without a valid reason.

In the prior audit, It was noted that fuel consumption for some vehicles was within the standard consumption rates except Vehicles for Route Capital, Thome, Mesora, Bypass, Saika, Hunters, Komarock which had consumed excess fuel of 5.28L, 8L, 4.4L,1.83 L, 9.50 L, 24.13L and 4.73 Litres respectively.
Motor vehicle fuel consumption analysis was done for the period 1st June 2025 to 16th June 2025, to evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
Some vehicles were found to be consuming within the set standards except for three vehicles namely KDB 197D, KCG 204S and KCK 047X
Transport/Fleet Department
To evaluate compliance with set fuel consumption standard for each vehicle.
